ProcedureHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: PROC SEQTEST <options> ;
    
The purpose of the SEQTEST procedure is to perform interim analyses for clinical trials. 
Clinical trials are experiments on human beings to demonstrate the efficacy and safety 
of new drugs or treatments. A simple example is a trial to test the effectiveness of a 
new drug in humans by comparing the outcomes in a group of patients who receive the new 
drug with the outcomes in a comparable group of patients who receive a placebo. 

A clinical trial is conducted according to a plan called a protocol. A protocol details 
the objectives of the trial, the data collection process, and the analyses of the data. 
The protocol contains information such as a null hypothesis and an alternative hypothesis, 
a test statistic, the probability α of a Type I error (incorrectly rejecting the null 
hypothesis), the probability β of a Type II error (incorrectly accepting the null hypothesis), 
the sample size needed to attain a specified power (probability of correctly rejecting the 
null hypothesis) of 1-β at an alternative reference, and critical values that are associated 
with the test statistic for hypothesis testing.

ProcedureOptionHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: BETABOUNDARY=BINDING | NONBINDING 
      
Specifies whether the β boundary is used in the computation of the Type I error level α.

ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Computes the Type I error probability with the β (acceptance) boundary.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Computes the Type I error probability without the β boundary.

ProcedureOptionHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: BETAOVERLAP=ADJUST | NOADJUST
OVERLAP=ADJUST | NOADJUST

Specifies whether to check for overlapping of the lower and upper β boundaries for the two corresponding
one-sided tests at the current and subsequent interim stages. This option applies to two-sided designs
with early stopping to accept Ho, or to either accept or reject Ho.

ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: The type of overlapping might result from a small β spending at an interim stage. When you  specify BETAOVERLAP=ADJUST, the procedure checks for this type of overlapping at the current and  subsequent interim stages. If such overlapping is found, the β boundaries for the two-sided design  at that stage are set to missing, and the β spending values at subsequent stages are adjusted.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: You can specify BETAOVERLAP=NOADJUST to request that no adjustment be made. The default is BETAOVERLAP=ADJUST.

ProcedureOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: BOUNDARY=SAS-data-set] 
      
Names the required SAS data set containing the design boundary information.

Specifies methods for boundary adjustments if an information level at a stage does not have a matched 
information level in the original design. The default is BOUNDARYADJ=ERRLINE.

ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies that the cumulative error spending at each interim stage not be changed, even if the  corresponding information level has been changed.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies the linear interpolation method for the adjustment.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: [Syntax: ERRFUNCGAMMA<(GAMMA=value)>]                                  Specifies the γ function method for the adjustment.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: Specifies the approximate O’Brien-Fleming cumulative error spending function for the adjustment.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip5: Specifies the approximate Pocock cumulative error spending function for the adjustment.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip6: [Syntax: ERRFUNCPOW<(RHO=value)>]                                  Specifies the power function method for the adjustment. The RHO= suboption specifies the power  parameter p in the function.

ProcedureOptionHelp.#cdata:
Specifies methods for boundary adjustments if an information level at a stage does not have a matched 
information level in the original design. The default is BOUNDARYADJ=ERRLINE.

ALPHA specifies the adjustment method for the α (rejection) boundary of a one-sided design or the 
lower and upper α boundaries of a two-sided design.

ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies that the cumulative error spending at each interim stage not be changed, even if the  corresponding information level has been changed.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies the linear interpolation method for the adjustment.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: [Syntax: ERRFUNCGAMMA<(GAMMA=value)>]                                  Specifies the γ function method for the adjustment.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: Specifies the approximate O’Brien-Fleming cumulative error spending function for the adjustment.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip5: Specifies the approximate Pocock cumulative error spending function for the adjustment.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip6: [Syntax: ERRFUNCPOW<(RHO=value)>]                                  Specifies the power function method for the adjustment. The RHO= suboption specifies the power  parameter p in the function.

ProcedureOptionHelp.#cdata:
Specifies methods for boundary adjustments if an information level at a stage does not have a matched information level in the original design. 
The default is BOUNDARYADJ=ERRLINE. 

LOWERALPHA specifies the adjustment method for the lower α boundary of a two-sided design

ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies that the cumulative error spending at each interim stage not be changed, even if the  corresponding information level has been changed.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies the linear interpolation method for the adjustment.

ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip6: [Syntax: ERRFUNCPOW<(RHO=value)>]                                  Specifies the power function method for the adjustment. The RHO= suboption specifies the power  parameter p in the function.

BETA specifies the adjustment method for the β (acceptance) boundary of a one-sided design or the lower and upper β boundaries of a two-sided design.

LOWERBETA specifies the adjustment method for the lower β boundary of a two-sided design.

Specifies methods for boundary adjustments if an information level at a stage does not have a matched information level in the original design. 
The default is BOUNDARYADJ=ERRLINE.

UPPERBETA specifies the adjustment method for the upper β boundary of a two-sided design.

ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies that the cumulative error spending at each interim stage not be changed, even if the  corresponding information level has been changed.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies the linear interpolation method for the adjustment.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: [Syntax: ERRFUNCGAMMA<(GAMMA=value)>]                                  Specifies the γ function method for the adjustment.

ProcedureOptionHelp.#cdata: Specifies the boundary key to be maintained in the boundary adjustments.

ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Maintains the Type I error probability level α and derives Type II error probability.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Maintains the Type II error probability level β and derives Type I error probability.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Maintains both α and β levels simultaneously by deriving a new maximum information.

ProcedureOptionHelp.#cdata: Specifies the boundary scale to be displayed in the boundaries for the output boundary table and boundary plots.

ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Corresponds to the boundary with the maximum likelihood estimator scale.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Corresponds to the boundary with the score statistic scale.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Corresponds to the boundary with the standardized normal Z scale.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: Corresponds to the boundary with the p-value scale.

ProcedureOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: CIALPHA=<(<LOWER=al> <UPPER=au>)>] 
      
Specifies the significance levels for the confidence interval, where 0 < p < 1,  0 < al < 0.5, 
and 0 < au < 0.5. The default is CIALPHA= 0.05.
Specifies the type of confidence interval.

[Syntax: DATA <(TESTVAR=variable)>=SAS-data-set] 
      
Names the SAS data set containing the test statistics and information levels.

[Syntax: ERRSPENDMIN<(boundary)>=numbers] 
      
Specifies the minimum error spending values at interim stages for the boundary. The default 
is ERRSPENDMIN=0. 
      
Use this if a set of numbers is used for each boundary in the design. Otherwise, use one of 
the ERRSPENDMIN(boundary)=numbers options.

Specifies the minimum error spending values for the α boundary of a one-sided design or the lower 
and upper α boundaries of a two-sided design.
Specifies the minimum error spending values for the lower α boundary of a two-sided design.
Specifies the minimum error spending values for the upper α boundary of a two-sided design.

Specifies the minimum error spending values for the β boundary of a one-sided design or the lower and upper
β boundaries of a two-sided design.
Specifies the minimum error spending values for the lower β boundary of a two-sided design.
Specifies the minimum error spending values for the upper β boundary of a two-sided design.

[Syntax: MAXINFO=number] 
      
Specifies the maximum information for the clinical trial if the information is not available from 
the variable _Info_ in the DATA= data set.

[Syntax: NSTAGES=number] 
      
Specifies the number of stages for the clinical trial.

Specifies the ordering of the sample space (k,z), where k is the stage number and z is the observed 
standardized Z statistic.

ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies the LR ordering that compares the distances between observed standardized Z statistics and  their corresponding hypothetical values.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies the MLE ordering that compares values in the MLE scale.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Specifies the stage-wise ordering that uses counterclockwise ordering around the continuous region.

ProcedureOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: PARMS <(TESTVAR=variable)> =SAS-data-set] 
      
Names the SAS data set containing the parameter estimates and their associated standard errors.

[Syntax: CONDPOWER <( CREF=numbers )> ] 
      
Displays conditional powers given the most recently observed statistic under specified hypothetical 
references. The default is CREF= 0 0.5 1.0 1.5.
Displays the error spending at each stage for each sequential boundary.
Displays predictive powers given the most recently observed statistic.

[Syntax: PSS <( CREF=numbers ) >] 
      
Displays powers and expected sample sizes under various hypothetical references. The default is 
CREF= 0 0.5 1.0 1.5.
Displays repeated confidence intervals for the parameter from the observed statistic at each stage.

[Syntax: STOPPROB <( CREF=numbers ) >] 
      
Displays expected cumulative stopping probabilities under various hypothetical references.
The default is CREF= 0 0.5 1.0 1.5.

Syntax: PLOTS <( ONLY )> <= plot-request> 
  PLOTS <( ONLY )> <= ( plot-request < ...plot-request> ) > 
         
Specifies options that control the details of the plots. The default is PLOTS=BOUNDARY.

ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: [Syntax: ASN<(CREF= numbers)>]                                  Displays a plot of the average sample numbers (expected sample sizes), under various hypothetical references.                                 For a one-sided design, the power and expected sample sizes under hypotheses θ=ci*thetha1 are  displayed, where θ1 is the alternative reference and ci are the values specified in the CREF= option.   For a two-sided design, the power and expected sample sizes under hypotheses θ=ci*thetha1l and  θ=ci*thetha1u are displayed, where thetha1l and thetha1u are the lower and upper alternative  references, respectively. The default is CREF=0 to 1.5 by 0.01.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: [Syntax: CONDPOWER<(CREF= numbers)>]                                  Displays a plot of conditional powers given the most recently observed statistic under specified  hypothetical references.                                 For a one-sided design, the power and expected sample sizes under hypotheses θ=ci*thetha1 are  displayed, where θ1 is the alternative reference and ci are the values specified in the CREF= option.   For a two-sided design, the power and expected sample sizes under hypotheses θ=ci*thetha1l and  θ=ci*thetha1u are displayed, where thetha1l and thetha1u are the lower and upper alternative  references, respectively. The default is CREF=0 to 1.5 by 0.01.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: [Syntax: ERRSPEND<(HSCALE=INFO | STAGE)>]                                  Displays a plot of the error spending for all sequential boundaries in the designs simultaneously.  You can display the information level (HSCALE=INFO) or the stage number (HSCALE=STAGE) on the horizontal  axis. With HSCALE=INFO, the information in percentage of its corresponding fixed-sample design is used in  the plot. The default is HSCALE=STAGE.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip6: [Syntax: POWER<(CREF= numbers)>]                                  Displays a plot of the power curves under various hypothetical references. For a one-sided design,  the power and expected sample sizes under hypotheses θ=ci*thetha1 are displayed, where θ1 is the  alternative reference and ci are the values specified in the CREF= option.   For a two-sided design, the power and expected sample sizes under hypotheses θ=ci*thetha1l and θ=ci*thetha1u are displayed,  where thetha1l and thetha1u are the lower and upper alternative references, respectively. The default is CREF=0 to 1.5 by 0.01.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip7: Displays a plot of repeated confidence intervals. Repeated confidence intervals include both rejection and acceptance confidence intervals.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip8: [Syntax: TEST<(HSCALE=INFO | SAMPLESIZE)>]                                  Displays a plot of the sequential boundaries and test variables. Either the information level  (HSCALE=INFO) or the sample size (HSCALE=SAMPLESIZE) is displayed on the horizontal axis.
